questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:  I started for school very late that morning and was in great dread of a scolding, especially because M. Hamel had said that he would question us on participles, and I did not know the first word about them. For a moment I thought of running away and spending the day out of doors. It was so warm, so bright! The birds were chirping at the edge of the woods; and in the open field back of the sawmill the Prussian soldiers were drilling. It was all much more tempting than the rule for participles, but I had the strength to resist, and hurried off to school.  When I passed the town hall there was a crowd in front of the bulletin-board. For the last two years all our bad news had come from there — the lost battles, the draft, the orders of the commanding officer — and I thought to myself, without stopping, “What can be the matter now?”  Then, as I hurried by as fast as I could go, the blacksmith, Wachter, who was there, with his apprentice, reading the bulletin, called after me, “Don’t go so fast, bub; you’ll get to your school in plenty of time!”  I thought he was making fun of me, and reached M. Hamel’s little garden all out of breath.  Usually, when school began, there was a great bustle, which could be heard out in the street, the opening and closing of desks, lessons repeated in unison, very loud, with our hands over our ears to understand better, and the teacher’s great ruler rapping on the table. But now it was all so still! I had counted on the commotion to get to my desk without being seen; but, of course, that day everything had to be as quiet as Sunday morning. Through the window I saw my classmates, already in their places, and M. Hamel walking up and down with his terrible iron ruler under his arm. I had to open the door and go in before everybody. You can imagine how I blushed and how frightened I was.  But nothing happened. M. Hamel saw me and said very kindly, “Go to your place quickly, little Franz. We were beginning without you.” I jumped over the bench and sat down at my desk.  - The Last Lesson- Alphonse Daudet

options.option_text: A person who works for another in order to learn a trade
A person who is qualified to treat people who are ill
A person who portrays a character in films
A person who designs machines and engines

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Foundation Level: Semester 1: English 1 (Computer-Based Exam)"** based on the question paper.
Since this is an **English proficiency/comprehension exam**, the focus is on **grammar, vocabulary, reading comprehension, listening skills, idioms, collocations, and communication skills**. No mathematical equations are relevant here.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension**
   - **Key Skills Tested**:
     - Understanding **main ideas**, **supporting details**, and **inferences** from passages.
     - Identifying **synonyms/antonyms** in context.
     - Answering **direct and indirect questions** about the text.
   - **Example Passage**: *"The Last Lesson"* by Alphonse Daudet (Questions 2–11).
     - Themes: **Fear of punishment**, **war (Prussian occupation)**, **regret**, **change in routine**.
     - Key vocabulary: *Participles, apprentice, bulletin-board, commotion, out of breath*.

#### **2. Grammar**
   - **A. Tenses**:
     - Present progressive (e.g., *"I’m looking for a research associate"* – Q53).
     - Past simple (e.g., *"Christ forgave his crucifiers"* – Q45).
   - **B. Subject-Verb Agreement**:
     - Collective nouns (e.g., *"Neither the coach nor the players **were** playing"* – Q44).
     - Plural/singular subjects (e.g., *"My friends and I **do not** want to go out"* – Q54).
   - **C. Articles**:
     - Indefinite/definite articles (e.g., *"She cooked up **a** story but it was not **the** first time"* – Q47).
   - **D. Active/Passive Voice**:
     - Identifying voice (e.g., *"The words of the opera are sung"* is **passive** – Q31).
   - **E. Error Spotting**:
     - Incorrect noun forms (e.g., *"delicacy"* → *"delicacies"* – Q56).
     - Wrong verb forms (e.g., *"I wish I **were** a child"* – Q57).

#### **3. Vocabulary**
   - **A. Synonyms/Antonyms**:
     - Synonym of *bustle*: **Commotion** (Q10).
     - Antonym of *common*: **Rare** (Q20).
   - **B. Word Collocations** (Q37–41):
     - *Coffee **shop***, *Birthday **party***, *High **school***, *Music **festival***, *Shopping **mall***.
   - **C. Idioms/Phrases** (Q48–49):
     - *Keep the ball rolling*: **Continue the work**.
     - *Get a taste of your own medicine*: **Be treated the way you treat others**.
   - **D. Stress and Syllables** (Q18–19, 33–36, 55):
     - Syllable count: *Locomotive* (4), *Transportation* (4), *Ordinary* (3).
     - Stress patterns: *Politics* (1st syllable), *Politician* (3rd syllable).

#### **4. Listening Skills** (Audio-Based Questions: Q12–17, 32–36)
   - **Key Themes**:
     - History of **railroads/trains** (delays, dirtiness, night travel, illumination).
     - **Pause and intonation** in sentences (e.g., *"And they were inspired to do so / because they saw a chance..."*).
   - **Skills Tested**:
     - Identifying **stressed syllables** (e.g., *politics*, *moment*).
     - Understanding **contextual clues** (e.g., why early trains were dirty: *"smoke from the engine"*).

#### **5. Communication Skills**
   - **A. Telephonic Conversations** (Q22–26):
     - Filling blanks with **appropriate responses**:
       - *"May I speak to Binitha?"* (Q22).
       - *"I’ve been trying to call you all day"* (Q23).
   - **B. Group Discussion Skills** (Q60–61):
     - **Not tested**: *In-depth knowledge of the topic*.
     - **Value-fit**: Alignment between **candidate’s values** and **company’s values**.

#### **6. Literary Devices & Figures of Speech**
   - **Irony**: Franz’s fear of scolding vs. M. Hamel’s kindness (*The Last Lesson*).
   - **Imagery**: *"Birds chirping at the edge of the woods"* (sensory details).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension & Vocabulary**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Main Idea]
    A --> C[Inference]
    A --> D[Vocabulary in Context]
    D --> E[Synonyms: Bustle → Commotion]
    D --> F[Antonyms: Common → Rare]
    A --> G[Passage: The Last Lesson]
    G --> H[Theme: Fear of Punishment]
    G --> I[Setting: Prussian Occupation]
```

#### **2. Grammar Rules**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Tenses]
    B --> B1[Present Progressive]
    B --> B2[Past Simple]
    A --> C[Subject-Verb Agreement]
    C --> C1[Collective Nouns]
    C --> C2[Plural/Singular Subjects]
    A --> D[Articles]
    D --> D1[Indefinite: a/an]
    D --> D2[Definite: the]
    A --> E[Active/Passive Voice]
    A --> F[Error Spotting]
```

#### **3. Listening & Communication Skills**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Listening Skills] --> B[Audio Comprehension]
    B --> B1[Train History]
    B --> B2[Stress/Pauses]
    A --> C[Telephonic Conversations]
    C --> C1[Appropriate Responses]
    C --> C2[Politeness]
    A --> D[Group Discussion]
    D --> D1[Value-Fit]
    D --> D2[Interpersonal Skills]
```

### **Key Takeaways for Exam Preparation**
1. **Reading Comprehension**:
   - Practice **summarizing passages** and **answering inferential questions**.
   - Focus on **historical/fictional passages** (e.g., *The Last Lesson*).

2. **Grammar**:
   - Revise **tenses**, **subject-verb agreement**, and **articles**.
   - Solve **error-spotting exercises**.

3. **Vocabulary**:
   - Learn **collocations** (e.g., *music festival*, *shopping mall*).
   - Memorize **synonyms/antonyms** and **idioms**.

4. **Listening**:
   - Practice **audio clips** for stress, pauses, and contextual understanding.

5. **Communication**:
   - Work on **telephonic conversation fillers** and **group discussion etiquette**.
